headline: Two new crocodile species discovered on islands in Quintana Roo
context: Researchers from McGill University in Montreal, in collaboration with Mexican scientists, have identified two previously unknown crocodile species inhabiting two islands off the Yucatán Peninsula.
Found on the renowned tourist island of Cozumel and within the Banco Chinchorro Biosphere Reserve 210 kilometers to the south, both new species remain unnamed, pending formal taxonomic description.

annotations.paragraph: Banco Chinchorro is an atoll reef — a ring-shaped coral formation with a central lagoon — off the southeast coast of Quintana Roo that’s popular with divers and snorkelers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information about Banco Chinchorro, which is not directly related to the discovery of the new crocodile species.

annotations.paragraph: The findings serve to fuel Mexicans’ longstanding cultural fascination with crocodiles, from pre-Hispanic times, when crocodiles were powerful symbols of fertility, rain and creation, to modern times, when out-and-about crocodiles always seem to make the news, whether they’re on the beach or crossing downtown streets or on the lam.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides cultural context about crocodiles in Mexico, which is not directly related to the discovery of the new species.

annotations.paragraph: The recent findings were published in Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution. Funding was provided by the Canadian Foundation for Innovation (CFI) and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC), along with Mexico’s National Commission of Natural Protected Areas (Conanp) and the Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature (FMCN).
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides publication and funding information related to the research, which is relevant to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: The discovery, announced last week in a news release from McGill’s Faculty of Science, stemmed from genetic and anatomical analyses of isolated populations, revealing stark differences from mainland American crocodiles, the type usually found in Mexico. Crocodylus acutus is its binomial name.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the discovery and the differences from known species, which is directly relevant.

annotations.paragraph: The findings have upended long-held assumptions about the American crocodile and underscore urgent conservation needs.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the implications of the discovery, which is relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: “Biodiversity is disappearing faster than we can discover what we’re losing,” said lead researcher Hans Larsson, a biology professor at McGill. “Most crocodile species are already endangered, and rapid shoreline development threatens nearly every population.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the urgency and threats to crocodile species, relevant to the discovery of new species.

annotations.paragraph: When researchers compared DNA sequences and skull morphology across Caribbean, Central American and Mexican Pacific crocodiles, they found the island populations were genetically distinct.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the method and findings that led to the discovery of the new species.

annotations.paragraph: “These results were totally unexpected,” said José Avila-Cervantes, the study’s lead author and a former McGill graduate student. “We assumed Crocodylus acutus was a single species ranging from Baja California to Venezuela. Our study is the first to extensively explore genomic and anatomical variation in these animals.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from a researcher about the significance of the findings.

annotations.paragraph: Each newly identified species has fewer than 1,000 breeding individuals, researchers added.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides important information about the population size of the new species.

annotations.paragraph: While current populations appear stable, their restricted habitats — Cozumel’s mangroves and Banco Chinchorro’s coral atoll — leave them vulnerable to coastal development and tourism.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the vulnerability of the new species' habitats, relevant to their conservation status.

annotations.paragraph: Banco Chinchorro, a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, offers stronger protections, but Cozumel’s fragmented ecosystems require immediate safeguards, researchers noted.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the conservation status and needs of the habitats where the new species were found.

annotations.paragraph: “The rapid loss of biodiversity can only be slowed if we know what species are most at risk,” Larsson said. “Limiting land development and implementing careful conservation strategies on Cozumel and Banco Chinchorro will be key to ensuring their survival.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a relevant quote about the importance of conservation for the newly discovered species.

annotations.paragraph: The research team included scientists from El Colegio de la Frontera Sur, a public scientific research center that addresses sustainable development and environmental and social challenges in Mexico’s southern border states.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background information about the research team, which is not directly relevant to the discovery of the new species.

annotations.paragraph: The team captured and released crocodiles to collect blood, scale and tissue samples.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes the methodology used to study the new species, which is relevant to the discovery.

annotations.paragraph: The study highlights how island isolation drives evolution, with ocean currents and habitat barriers fostering unique species.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant context about the evolutionary processes that may have led to the development of the new species.
